title: U.S. stocks shake off Target profit warning to erase losses
text:
* The Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA was up 60 points, or 0.2%, at 32,975.

* The S&P 500 SPX rose 16 points, or 0.4%, to 4,138.

* The Nasdaq Composite COMP gained 90 points, or 0.7%, to trade at 12,151.

On Monday, the Dow eked out a gain of less than 0.1%, the S&P 500 rose 0.3% and the Nasdaq Composite gained 0.4%.

What's driving markets

Target's TGT profit warning was blamed for adding to the negative tone for equities in early action. Target, ahead of the opening bell, announced a plan to reduce its inventory and revised its operating margin guidance. The plan includes canceling orders, markdowns, and removing inventory, along with price hikes to offset higher fuel and transportation costs, and increased holding capacity at the ports and other supply chain adjustments.

Target shares remained down around 1.5%, after dropping around 6% in early activity. They're down more than 40% from their 52-week high. Disappointing results from Target on May 18 sent stock indexes skidding, highlighting fears that surging inflation was beginning to cut into corporate earnings.

Several large retailers have delivered mixed earnings and outlooks in the latest quarterly reporting period, pressuring stock prices, as investors try to determine if their results suggest the start of a potential recession or just a switch from consumers spending on goods to services as the economy has recovered from the pandemic.

See: Target's steps to reduce inventory glut are correct but are a few weeks late, analyst says

Without major U.S. economic data due for release and Federal Reserve officials in a quiet period ahead of their next policy meeting on June 14-15, Treasury debt yields lurched higher on Monday, with the 10-year BX:TMUBMUSD10Yretaking the key 3% level but steadied on Tuesday. The U.S. May consumer-price index is due for release on Friday.

In One Chart: Why stock-market investors get 'squirrelly' when bond yields top 3%

In a paper published Monday, former U.S. Treasury Secretary Larry Summers argued there will need to beVolcker-style aggressiveness at the Federal Reserve to tame inflation. Former Federal Reserve Chairman Paul Volcker raised interest rates sharply to quell surging inflation, with the economy tipping into an early recession in the 1980s.

"Many are interpreting this finding as implying that the task facing Powell is almost as severe as the task that faced Volcker, that a similar amount of hawkish restraint — relative to today's neutral policy setting — might be required to do so, and that this would almost certainly end in recession," said Krishna Guha, vice chairman at Evercore ISI. Guha said his opinion is that Powell's task is not as difficult as Volcker's in the 1980s.

Meanwhile, the World Banksharply downgraded its outlook for the global economy, pointing to Russia's war against Ukraine, the prospect of widespread food shortages and concerns about the potential return of "stagflation" — a toxic mix of high inflation and sluggish growth unseen for more than four decades.

Companies in focus

* Kohl's Corp. KSS stock rose 12% after The Wall Street Journal reportedthat Franchise Group FRG is in talks to buy the department store operator for roughly $8 billion.

* Shares of Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co. GT fell 1.5% after the tire maker issued a safety recall of more than 173,000 tires due to a defect that has led to crashes that resulted in deaths and injuries, after initially declining a request for a recall.

* Apple AAPL rose, leading tech stocks, after revamping its MacBook Air and MacBook Pro laptops Monday while previewing new software features that will let people customize their iPhone screens more.

What other assets are doing

* The ICE U.S. Dollar Index DXY, a measure of the currency against a basket of six major rivals, was flat.

* Oil futures pushed higher, with the U.S. benchmark CL.1 up 1.2% near $120 a barrel. Gold futures GC00 rose 0.6% to trade near $1,854 an ounce.

* Bitcoin BTCUSD fell 4.7% to trade below $29,900.

* The Stoxx Europe 600 XX:SXXP fell 0.2%, while London's FTSE 100 UK:UKX was flat.

* The Shanghai Composite COMP edged up 0.2%, while the Hang Seng Index HK:HSI fell 0.6% in Hong Kong and Japan's Nikkei 225 JP:NIK ticked up 0.1%.
